reviewText: I was expecting this to be like those million other movies you find at the bottom of the $5 DVD barrel at Wal-mart, or the junk they show on the sci-fi channel at 2:30 in the morning, but this was very well done! I was captivated the entire time, even when my son picked out half of an almond joy from his pants and fooled me into thinking it was a piece of crap. Cute, right? Maybe if he wasn't 30! What's wrong with this kid? Where did I go wrong?

SPOILER ALERT- This movie is about time travel.  And, as interesting as that might seem, it was not entertaining  nor even thought provoking.  Total miss, with a twist at the end that was just silly.  Color me ... Unfulfilled

I liked this quirky movie! It brought to mind some fascinating scientific developments that have recently occurred. Too bad he went to visit Einstein cause Townsend Brown was the real life scientist who made startling scientific finds and little is known about his astounding research.

Wasn't certain about this movie at first, I worried it was going to be just another time travel flick; however, I was pleasantly surprised. The movie kept me engaged throughout and there were a couple of good twists. I definitely recommend this movie.

This is a slow going movie ,it  could have had so much  more potential . It was repetitive and boring . Another movie I couldn't wait to finish .The cast though I will say had some good acting and the dialog scenes were well done . For a second I could see the father and son on broadway . Quickly giving way to a boring script .

I hesitated to watch this movie, having seen so many sci fi versions of time travel movies. I'm very glad I chose to watch this.

Not only does the science behind the movie's premise come across as plausible (unlike most movies in this slice of sci fi), the characters and drama outside of the core concept is well done. You could remove the time travel concept from this movie, and a lot of the philosophical questions that the characters struggle with still stand.

I credit the screenplay, the direction, and several of the main characters for keeping this movie equal parts on the human condition, and on a hard sci fi premise for dealing with those "what if?" questions that everyone faces.
Not only was this movie intriguing and, IMHO, very good; but, it caught me off guard with some issues that made this movie somewhat of an emotional ride (that I was not expecting).
A great science fiction story intertwined with those meaningful family emotions that make you really feel something wonderful. I highly recommend it for the average science-fiction buff.

This is not a fast paced movie. It is more quiet than your typical science-fiction. It is a movie about three generations of scientists in a family who love each other deeply. Some of them are also passionate about their research. The movie gets the science right & the emotional aspects in the relationships also seem genuine. There are a lot of themes from the film that I think I'll be discussing with my husband long after the movie finished. I will see it again. Well worth the price.
It was good.
Excellent movie. I did not see the ending coming. If you like an unusual time travel story, this one I highly recommend.

I don't think Time Travel fans will enjoy this movie too much because the time travel aspect has little to with the story other than provide hope that the sad parts can be undone and have a happy ending.  The story focuses on the drama caused by a time traveler who travelled to the past and was unable to return, leaving his wife and kids feeling abondoned and thinking him dead.  When time travel is brought in, its almost not even a big deal, the bigger focus on the relationship between the Son and his girlfriend who he is now spending less time with.  This should be classied as a Drama 1st, then mystery/missing person,  and lastly Sci Fi.  There is no comedy or action here, no time travel paradoxes, no fancy time machine or special effects.
I can understand if people like the movie, but those wanting an interesting Time Travel plot should look elsewhere.
This was a lot better than I expected it to be. I'd definitely recommend it.

I was looking for some mild entertainment while doing some mindless paperwork, and this fit the bill perfectly. The story is not about the sci or the fi, but about the loss of a loved one and what you might do and how much you might risk to get them back.  It's not the only movie to consider the topic, but I thought it did a better job than most when it comes to portraying the trade-offs one might have to deal with in making that choice.  I found the ending unexpected and clever.

While "I'll Follow You Down" is not an awful movie and only nominally about time travel, it left me wishing I could get back about two-thirds of the time I spent watching it.  Fans of big CGI action films won't find much to appreciate here, nor will those who appreciate intelligent discourse.  This is a quiet, indie film that uses time travel to look at the lives of the people left behind when their husband/father disappears on a business trip.  Given the movie's sci-fi premise, with a little more attention to character and intellectual consistency and much less reliance on a slightly surprising twist at the end (which should have been entirely unnecessary, if the father had half a brain), this could have been a much better movie.

The story is good, and interesting. I think the producer has got most out of such a cheap movie. But as a science student, I think the ending is not quite self-explanatory. The theory here is "parallel universe", so no matter what Eric do, he can only change the life path of himself in the other universe together with his coming back live father and happy family, not the tragic one of that has been set up particular him. Therefore, instead of committing a suicide (sorry to be a spoiler) at the end which changes nothing than adding sadness to his already broken GF at (the time-traveling version) his universe, he should just travel back to the universe belongs to him, and wish the good luck of the other version of him live a happy and good life ever since. This kind of ending might not be as surprising as the movie has, but indeed a more logic and scientific one. But every coin has two side, my suggested type of ending may just bring down the rating of the movie, who knows, LOL. In a word, a good time travel film, may be better in some sense.

An interesting story definitely worth the time. The story blends time travel with the compulsion to change the turn of events. A happily married couple is torn apart when the husband, a noted scientist, has gone missing. The wife, played by Gillian Anderson, is devastated by the loss and never fully recovers. Their son, played by Haley Joel Osment, and the grandfather try to complete the father's work and try to find him in time. This is a drama of love, loss and sacrifice. And, happy endings. Sorry for being a spoiler.
A very interesting sci-fi plot with a totally unexpected twist at the end. Yet that ending, in retrospect, was a necessary one. Definitely a must-see movie for sci-fi fans.

The characters are believable (while the basic theme of time travel requires that one completely suspend disbelief), and the story has a very unexpected outcome. Language is mild and, with the exception of one moment of violence, it is a film that can be watched by almost the entire family, children under about the age of twelve excepted (mostly because it may not hold their interest).

For Sci-Fi aficionados the "science" will drive you nuts.  They start talking about alternate universes and then say "We'll reset and correct everything and it'll all change to be different, we'll never know the difference!"  Yeah guys that's not how it works...  That's the 'Back to the Future' logic where alternate timelines don't exist.  It's fun to speculate either way, but please don't bring up alternate timelines and then act like those alternate timelines won't exist anymore.

How two 'scientists' can never have the conversation that it's possible all timelines will continue existing is mind boggling.

For drama's sake, I get why they want the Back to the Future model.  Which is fine.  Just don't mess up your story by talking about quantum theory when you don't understand it.

It's not SciFi. SciFi is a self-consistent extension of reality, containing, at least, reasonable application of the scientific method to be able to tell an interesting story. The time travel aspect is neither self-consistent nor well-founded, just a ridiculous idea of time travel that the director tries to hide by not confronting it. Also, it purports to star Rufus Sewell, who, e.g. Dark City, would be great in a real SciFi film, but he's got about 10 minutes of screen time. In the last 5 minutes, the movie might earn another star or two from some, but otherwise it's standard hollywood garbage.

This movie is slower-moving than the usual science fiction movie. It represents a different kind of science fiction movie, one that is responsible, one that considers the ramifications of new knowledge. In this way, it is excellent. It is also about sacrifices that one makes in order to put things right.

The acting in this movie is excellent. Gillian Anderson is very convincing as the distraught widow. Haley Joel Osment is convincing as a young man torn between choices. This is a science fiction movie with a compassion and sensitivity.

Wow!  Did this one ever surprise me!

Rotten Tomatoes gives it 33% on 9 reviews.  I was sure it was a stinker.

The problem, however, is that this is smart science fiction.  This is what science fiction is supposed to be!  The low rating is not because there is anything wrong with the film; the problem is that the reviewers are not intelligent enough to appreciate it.

They had these polls to find the best Star Trek episodes.  From the original series the winner was The Trouble with Tribbles.  For the Next Generation it was the one where Picard's mind was hijacked by a machine that caused him to live the life of an alien whose civilization was destroyed; he fell in love, married, had children, grew old.  There are all these Star Trek episodes where there are titanic battles with ray guns firing all over the place, blowing up space stations and spaceships, but the episodes that fans judged to be the best were the ones that were human in scale.  One was a silly comedy and the other was a sincere depiction of life and love.

That is what this movie is.  It is a depiction of what the human side of time travel would be.  It is about the love of family members for each other.

This is an unusually smart science fiction film.  It might help you to become a better person.
Entertaining.  Not the best movie not the worst.

I wish they'd paid another $50 and got a better screen writer.  It was hard to watch such a conspicuous lack of insight about human characters, the research process, simple logic and physics.  On the other hand, as movie watchers we are so hard up for anything, anything imaginative whatsoever, I want to be gracious.  At least someone here made the effort.

What feels like alot of foreshadowing turns out to actually be clever twists and turns, but not to the point that it becomes silly. And is it just me, or did anybody else see dead people? In truth, could have been another generic genre movie, but by avoiding common pitfalls and focusing on the characters, a surprisingly excellent movie.

In theory, science fiction permits the exploration of ideas that would be difficult otherwise to elaborate when confined to a more traditional narrative. In the literature of science fiction this freedom has resulted in some truly imaginative and important works such as Fahrenheit 451, parts of Asimov's Foundation series, and Shute's On the Beach. Interesting sci-fi movies are much more rare, and among the few examples is of course 2001 A Space Odyssey as well as the lesser-known Coherence.

Most sci-fi, however, is merely tedious reworking of existing genres with a thin layer of magic-tech over the surface. Examples include the genre of cowboys-in-space (Star Wars, Star Trek, The Martian) and soap-opera-in-space (also Star Wars). Worst of all are sci-fi movies that have pretentions to actual  science but the script writers/editors are so scientifically illiterate that they get the basics totally wrong. Gravity and Interstellar are merely two recent examples of this sort of infantile nonsense.

Sadly, I'll Follow You Down belongs firmly in the latter camp. The basic setup has potential: a man invents a time machine (that is, apparently, wonderfully economical with its use of power, but we'll let that slide...) and goes back to 1946 where he is unexpectedly mugged and killed. Thus he never returns to his original time and from that failure to return follows the rest of the story.

The man's son, being also a mathematical genius, eventually determines (with the help of his also-a-maths-whiz professorial grandfather) that their present timeline is "wrong" and can be modified if he, the son, intercepts his father in the past to make everything right again ("how it should have been"). Now in principle this is a really interesting setup. The protagonists have lived out 12 years on this "wrong" timeline. If the timeline is "corrected" they will cease to exist and alternates of themselves will live out a different timeline. But the current protagonists will cease to exist. There is thus an existential question: should the protagonists cancel out their own existence in favor of analogs who will then live the "correct" timeline? Is it ethical to eradicate everyone you know in order to restore a hypothetical "correct" timeline? This is a question of identity. What does it mean to say "another me" will take my place if I suddenly cease to exist? What might I owe that "other" me and all the "other" protagonists whose lives were affected by the time-travel event?

Furthermore, what if the entire question is irrelevant? In other words, the protagonists in the current timeline are basically trapped there and it will play out according to the logic of the father never returning whereas the alternate timeline will play out (where the father does return) because the two timelines fork at the zero point and this fork is now fundamental to the twin timelines existing in parallel but never touching.

These are really interesting questions and could have led to a fascinating script.

But these questions are never asked (indeed I doubt the script writers even understood they are implicit in the setup) and therefore never explored. Instead we just have a tedious slow-paced soap opera that reflects on nothing, explores nothing, and leads to nothing. I'm not really sure whether or not this is because movie makers assume no one out there is interested in thought-provoking movies, or because movie makers tend to be intellectually limited and therefore trapped in the tiny rooms of their own cramped imaginations.

Whichever the case, this is just another dull movie that asks nothing of its audience and gives nothing in return. The allusion to "negative energy" resulting from the movement of two frames of reference (a hilariously inept view of the Lorenz transformations that are central to Einstein's first paper on relativity) is apt only in the sense that this movie sucks the energy out of what could have been an interesting concept and leaves us with an overall negative: the time spent watching it was wasted and could better have been used doing something else instead.

The nostalgic look of the film, excellent acting, light humor and heavy trauma come together in an unforgettable story.

I absolutely loved The Time Machine (book & movie) as a kid. My father was a sci-fi nut & took us kids to every movie (sci-fi or not) that came along during the 1950s/60s. Dad had a telescope that we used frequently, also a microscope. He was a geologist who helped mapped Antarctica. But he also suffered horrible PTSD (we called them "rage fits"). I often wondered what might have happened had he not served in WWII where he saw his BF's head blown off by a kamakazi pilot/gunner.
So this film hit me in so many ways. I grew up around scientists/explorers--people like my father who risked their lives (in war & also mapping Antarctica in the early 1960s, living in igloos--Dad has a glacier & a mountain peak in Antarctica named after him (Elder glacier/peak) due to the fact that he nearly died on an icy promontory during a blizzard while there.
Altho' I went another route, teaching English Lit', doing art & writing poetry (many published in literary journals), I have kept my love for science and also hoped that someone would figure out how to travel in time.
There is very little violence in this film. Thank Heavens--no car chases, no shoot-outs. But it is deeply compelling & exciting. I felt utter thrills in watching the particle scientists work on their theory, trying to make it into reality. So many science fiction ideas have come true, so anything is possible.
Without giving spoilers, I will say that Gillian Anderson ripped out my soul with her performance. I've always loved Rufus Sewell and he is wonderful in this film, too.
John Paul Ruttan is perfect as the young Erol. Victor Garber is compelling as the obsessed grandfather (of Erol). Haley Joel Osmet is fantastic as the adult Erol. Susanna Fournier is touching as Grace. In fact, all the actors are brilliant.
The music by Andrew Lockington is perfect throughout.
The cinematography by Tico Poulakakis is utterly elegant. Richie Mehta, director, is a genius.
Watch this film! You will love it.

This is a very cool time travel story told from the a heart-felt, perspective of the family who were victims of the patriarch's selfish desires to perfect Einstein's theories on the subject.  I am a huge sci-fi fan and have grown accustomed to fantastical landscapes created through warping space-time and anxiously awaiting the results from some group or individual making waves in time lines in alternate universes.  However, this story was pleasantly emotional and I enjoyed seeing the emotional states of the family left behind, take their painfully tragic turns.  Normally you see them driving the story and typically see the time traveler(s) imposing their wills and satisfying their desires (misguided or not).  Much of those types of stories are guided by them.
This story is VERY different.  It is really refreshing to see, in this case, the emotional toll taken on the family left behind and how that pain is used as the driver to set things right by the son.  The story was kind of slow, but there is as much a character study in play when the the leads have taken such emotional dives as a result of what happened, that I guess it's to be expected.  The story isn't as woefully linear as it easily could have been, so I'm glad time was apropriately taken to explore the emotional states of the mother, son and the grandfather.  The son's reluctance at times, is mainly what keeps this from being predictably linear, so kudos to the writers and the director.
The emotional high-point for me, came at the end.  WOW! What a shocker.  The son knew how reluctant his father would be in traveling back to the present with haste, in order to resolve the horrible ends of those left behind in the present.  Knew his father so well, in fact, that what he set up to ensure his father complied was well...shocked the daylights out of me, for sure.  FANTASTIC ENDING!!!
I give this movie 5 stars because it hit all the marks of a wonderfully told piece of science fiction and the the perspective from which it was told and how carefully and beautifully it lays out the cost of what happens when selfish choices are made for the sake of personal, scientific discovery at the expense of those we love - without having carefully thought out the consequences. AND it did it without having to use the special effects sequences we've come to expect with sci-fi stories dealing with time travel.
Really kewl movie!!!

His grandfather's entire premise is based on the idea of alternate realities.  In other words, an infinite number of universes which are continuously created at every juncture created by a decision point.  According to him, they have been placed in their own unique timeline from the point which his father left.  Erol repeatedly assures his girlfriend that their life will be somehow better after he goes back and alters his father's path.  The issue with that is, he is not altering their reality.  Only the one that he somehow left years ago when his father died.  From her perspective, he will have left and disappeared in the same manner that his father did so many years before.

So, in theory, this story is about time travel and the ramifications of one person changing history through the eyes of the people he left behind.

In actuality this is a story about how Haley Joel Osment's character is surrounded by the most selfish people in existence.

Spoilers ahead.

HJO's dad abandons his wife and child to travel back in time to meet his childhood hero, without anything set in place in case the TOTALLY UNTESTED and UNBELIEVABLY DANGEROUS experiment he's been constructing in TOTAL SECRECY goes wrong.  In a shocking turn of events, he doesn't come back from the past. Who could have seen this coming.

This makes HJO terrified of people leaving him so he devotes 100% of his time and energy to making the people around him happy, mostly his mother and his girlfriend. It is stated by multiple characters in text that he is almost absurdly invested in making them happy so they'll stick around. Then, the second he doesn't indulge his mother in reminiscing about his dead and/or deadbeat dad, she kills herself. Just straight up kills herself in the house they both live in with the last memory HJO has of her being their fight and he is the one to find her body. Mother of the year.

Then, when he becomes more invested in time travel to try and bring his father back and less invested in his girlfriend, she starts out by basically pouting and throwing temper tantrums. Later on it's better explained that she's always nervous, always on the edge, because any second could be her last in this life when HJO changes the past. But before that's explained, and even after, she comes off as being incredibly selfish that HJO isn't constantly waiting on her hand and foot like he used to.

The only character who isn't a selfish douchebag, besides HJO himself, is his grandfather who just wants to bring back Deadbeat Dad to make his daughter happy again. He doesn't push anytime HJO says no and does what he can on his own.

The story itself doesn't really have a structure. Instead of 3 act it's more like A-Z acts with no theme connecting them. The ending was...dreary. Like it is meant to end on a happy note but the character we've spent the entire movie with is basically punished? For having s***ty people around him?? And no one really learned anything, except maybe Deadbeat Dad but only when the knowledge was FORCED on him after he refused it over and over because, well, Deadbeat Dad is Deadbeat.

The idea was good, I really liked HJO's character, but I spent most of the film indignant on his behalf and that's not really an emotion I look for when watching a movie.

I really liked this movie. I was excited about the brainy side of the movie, but I also agreed with the female (I can't remember her name, erel's girlfriend). She felt everything would change if time reset. She worried there baby would never happen. In the end, he does it and goes back in time to talk his father to go home and never go back in time again. It has asad and shocking ending.

Although this movie is nominally about time travel, it is in fact primarily a movie about love, family and the consequences of decisions. When the protagonist's father disappears when he is nine years old the consequences for his future are catastrophic. Still, when, as a man, he is offered an opportunity to correct this disaster, the son is reluctant to do so because it will be at the cost of tthe life which he has created for himself in the aftermath of his father's death. I can't give this movie five stars because I felt that its ending, although both dramatic and credible, found too  easy a solution to the really terrible dillemma it initially established, but later retreated from. Nevertheless I think it is well worth watching for its frank exploration of the pain that arises from having to choose between the people and the things we love. .

Have you ever been talking to someone on the phone and have them tell you that they're about to run out of minutes but to "keep talking"? You know how you stand there after the line goes dead with an unfinished conversation in your head and been frustrated because what you had to say was important? And, because they're out of minutes, you can't call them back.

That's what the ending of this movie was like. It was like the director ran out of minutes during the most important moment in the conversation.

I love stories in all forms--books, movies, plays, ballads, radio shows, etc.  As a fan of a good story, I don't care whether the science behind time travel is sound.  I care about the story and I really care about the ending. Let's face it, the ending makes the suffering we go through with the characters worth the journey. It doesn't have to be happy, but the wrap up is important. When there's no wrap up, when the key question is unanswered, I feel cheated. Good endings can go a long way toward saving a bad movie. But a bad ending can ruin an otherwise good movie.

The acting was good (am a fan of Gillian Anderson), the script was fine, the and the story was dark, but intriguing. I was invested. I wanted to know if the gamble paid off. If everyone was happier for the decisions made. Instead I got an unfinished conversation. Credits were rolling and I was staring at the screen, praying for a call back that never came.
The movie was well connected and you only find out at the end how much reality was already modified by the inevitable rescue of the dad by the son.

I found it in no way as surprising or twisty as others have commented, but instead a fairly straight forward exploration about the impacts of our life's choices against the things that we hold dear.  Worth the viewing!!

Victor Garber and Gillian Anderson are wonderful actors, and the rest of the cast is perfectly solid. Some other reviewers seem to be confusing the quality of the acting with the quality of the writing and direction. They shouldn't. But they are quite correct that the story is just wretched on multiple levels.

Right off the bat, science fiction too often is treated like a kind of film ghetto where genuine plausibility and realism is utterly optional. I'm talking about fundamental things, not the SF elements themselves. In "Interstellar," to cite an example, they postulate that NASA was quietly given funding in the midst of civilization's collapse to pay for a last-ditch effort to find a new home for humanity ... but, somehow, the agency utterly neglected to recruit and train a new batch of top-notch astronauts in the process. Nope, they had to go to bizarre lengths -- involving drones and weirdball clues -- to lure a retread out of retirement over to their secret nest. Nevermind the science, this is not plausible in any respect. It wouldn't be plausible in ANY story, sci fi or not. So, too, here. Honestly: do you think that there are crates locked up ANYWHERE, marked "Property of Albert Einstein", that have been left to gather dust in nearly-forgotten basement storerooms? Really? That's absurd. Yeah, I'll cheerfully suspend my disbelief IF the filmmaker is willing to earn it. But they don't earn it, they scarcely even try.

Okay, let's jump past the heaps of plausibility speed bumps in this film. But then we get to where the rubber meets the road in any film that tries to claim a science fiction mantle: the SCIENCE. Now how do I put this? Oh, yeah: in this film, there is NO science. None. Nada, Zippo. Mumbo-jumbo and big sciency-sounding words must carry all the weight.

Right off the bat, this is almost inevitable because this is a time-travel film. Some people love those. I will give one a pass if it has enough other elements to make the ride a lot of fun ("Back to the Future" anyone?). But rarely are time-travel tales worth anything, because they run smack into horrific contradictions. In this one, the scientist's son travels back to save his dad from an untimely death in the past. Well, okay ... and if he succeeds, then he was never in a position (or had a need) to do this, so he wouldn't, so no one would come back to save dad, so dad would die, so the son would then have reason to come back to save him, so dad would live, so the son would not be in a position ....

See what I mean? That's why so many good SF writers really try to avoid time travel yarns as a matter of policy. Too many problems start at the conceptual level. Here's another one: the idea that a couple of math whizzes could whack out a working time machine in the basement with some sheet metal, a few blocks of styrofoam, and lots of spit and string. I could enjoyably accept that notion when the film was, say, "Time After Time," and it was all about H.G. Wells having a REAL time machine with which to chase Jack the Ripper. (Hell, his machine looked so much cooler, too. This one looks like a recycled contestant's booth from "The $54,000 Question.") Well, Time After Time wasn't making the least pretense at being science fiction. It was fantasy from the get-go. This film, by contrast, offers nothing fun and catchy, so there really has to be some plausible science. And there just isn't.

Another example: turns out they need to account for the earth's motion in the decades since 1946 (a minor plot device, also, in Time After Time). But the calculations just don't work ... until -- well snap my suspenders -- they forgot to account for earth quakes which moved the earth's crust slightly. Really? Like real scientists wouldn't have considered tectonic issues thoroughly if tracking the earth's precise movements through 50 odd years was vital? Moreover, the film makes clear they haven't included our solar system's own slow rotation within the Milky Way galaxy ... or the galaxy's motions relative to the rest of the universe. They thought they were being clever just mentioning adjustments for leap years.

Bottom line: don't waste your time on this one. Several of the cast are really quite terrific, but their performances just can't do the heavy lifting necessary in a muddled and dubious script to make this dog worth watching.

Not outstanding, but not a total stinker, either.  A son, very young when his father disappeared on a business trip, grows up, and with the help of his grandfather, unravels the clues that leads the son to attempt a time travel experiment in order to prevent his mother's suicide,and bring his father back.  The not so great part, is that the mother is totally co-dependent, leading to her demise.  This gives a poor message to young women.  On the bright side, this movie could be used to bring up the issue of co-dependence with a young woman and set her straight.  The son's girlfriend also lives in fear of losing him should he be successful at returning his father to the present.  Keeping in mind that movies/television shows are designed to formulate the mind set/belief system of viewers, (in this case that women are nothing without a man, and that women/women's needs are secondary to those of a male, or are not important), you might find this movie somewhat amusing.

I enjoyed this time travel movie. It wasn't the best one I've seen, but it certainly wasn't the worst. I'm kind of addicted to anything that has to do with time travel, so I've seen them all, I think. Of course I didn't understand all the math stuff, but that doesn't matter. What matters is that the movie makes you think and after you've seen it, you're still thinking about it, even a few days later.  The idea that IF the son goes back in time and prevents his father from one fate, then he will live the life that he is intended to live, instead of living out the life he has been living, is an intriguing concept. Haven't we all thought about something that we've done or something that has happened to us and had the thought "If I had just left the house a minute later than I did, that wouldn't have happened, and my whole life would be different," or "If I hadn't gone to that party, then I wouldn't have met so-and-so, and my life would be totally different," etc.  That's sort of what the theme of this movie is, except it's dependent on time travel and one man's choice, followed by his son's choice later on. I think it's definitely worth seeing.

This is really a surprising movie with beautiful acting and an unexpected ending.  Haley Joe Osment is excellent in it, as is Gillian Anderson, and Victor Garber.  It is really nice to see someone such as Haley Joe continuing to act as an adult.  So many child stars seem to quit acting when they become adults and aren't so "adorable" anymore.  However, he was always a fine actor and has just gotten better with time.  It takes awhile for the story to unfold and it seems slow, at first, but with patience it builds into quite an amazing story of time travel, accidents, and the effects that trying to change time has on the lives of everyone involved.  I gave it four stars because so much of the video is dark (as in not enough light on the set) so it can be hard to see at times.  Otherwise, a very interesting movie.

I came across this while scrolling through films last night looking for something to watch. It's a decent film, and totally worth it if you're a sci-fi fan. I always look for films with Rufus Sewell. He was great in Dark City, but since then he seems to be stuck playing a sneering villain (you might remember him in A Knight's Tale or The Illusionist (Widescreen Edition). He's appealing as a positive character here, but with a dark side, and perhaps some hidden motivations. Haley Joel Osment is very good in this as well. He hasn't shaken free from his Sixth Sense persona really, and this was a good choice for him. Also good is the X-Files' Gillian Anderson. What I liked most was that this was an actor driven story, not special effects driven. You get so used to seeing explosions every two seconds, that it's nice to see a film that develops dramatic tension in other ways. There is a bit of a time travel element here, but the actual treatment of time travel is more in a theoretical sense (which is refreshing). There is a diner scene at the end that's reminiscent of Predestination, but don't be put off, this is a much more approachable sci-fi flick (I liked Predestination...but it's intense). Good human element, good story, good acting. It's also well-conceived and directed. Give it a look if you're looking for something thoughtful to keep you entertained.

After giving top ratings to a TV series - several times in fact - I woke up one day and found it was no longer free on "Prime." Since that happened, I have been hesitant to rate anything. I will not want to watch it again like I might have wanted to watch certain TV series I can no longer watch for free on Prime, but it was OK.

Since I won't want to watch it again, I have rated it a conservative 3  stars. Maybe it was (a lot) better than that, but Amazon has perverted the process by punishing us for rating various programs / movies too high. I will never make that stupid mistake again.

First of all, saying this is "starring" Gillian Anderson is a misnomer.  Certainly she is in it but hardly in a starring role.  This actually stars Haley Joel Osment and Victor Garber.

Osment, as the adult Erol is son of missing father, Gabriel (Rufus Sewell).  Erol is a math genius as was his father and grandfather Sal (Garber).  Sal posits to Erol his father was working on a time machine.  Eventually Erol comes to grips with this and decides to go back and find his missing father.

This is an ingenious plot and the acting is fairly solid.  It entertains and didn't leave the viewer scratching their head at the end of it.

Time Warp?: Does Einstein's general relativity theory really prove (or at least imply) the possibility of traveling back in time? Nolan's recent "Interstellar" also lays out a take on the warping of space and time. Hard to distinguish between science and science fiction. At least Kip Thorne consulted on "Interstellar". Not sure who consulted on "I'll Follow You Down." In any case, an interesting take.

Phenomenal movie that closely examines what real-life consequences would come from forms of time travel in their infancy; the destruction they could cause when poorly planned and executed, while not physical in nature by necessity, would leave very real and visceral scars. This movie is just that; no tears in reality, no insane, backwards, Doctor Who style time warps that change everything, just the honest, aching pain of a family suddenly left without their father. As a lover of science fiction and a member of the very exciting technological age we live in, I feel that these kinds of examinations are what will truly stand the test of time, as we come face to face with their real-life counterparts in the years to come.

Until the end, I gave this movie the benefit of the doubt, waiting for my pay-off.  But when the ending came, I thought: what?  That's the conclusion?  I felt short-changed.
I gave it two stars instead of the one the script deserves, only because I like Gillian Anderson, and I also like the actor who plays her father, Victor Garber.  They were more or less sufficient in their roles.  Anderson was believable as her character.  I didn't care for the script's tendency to blame her husband for how she fared in the bulk of the movie, however.
Garber, who exudes integrity, nevertheless didn't strike me as the kind of world-changing genius that he'd have to be to do what he did in the movie.  Ditto for Osment.  Additionally, the idea that Garber and Osment allegedly did what they did as a duo (free of the help of other geniuses) wasn't close to being believable.
Einstein gets passing attention in this movie.  In actual life, Einstein didn't achieve what he did, all alone.  Yes, he made tremendous advances with theoretical physics problems, and yes, he was a visionary.  However, there were many other scientists around the world who were looking at similar challenges, and these scientists were in communication with him.  Einstein's correspondence acknowledges how their input was helpful to his progress.  But this dog of a script would have us believe that there is such a thing as a "one man show" (or a two-man show) when it comes to humanity's quantum leap discoveries.  It's wrong in so many ways.
The minor role of Anderson's husband (a character who mostly appeared in absentia) was under-utilized.  There was nothing about this man that was memorable, likeable, or symbolic of the true time explorer he was supposed to be.  Nothing.  As a viewer, I wanted to connect to him more (for the sake of the story), but there was nothing to connect to.  Waste of a character.
Regarding couple chemistry, there was more genuine chemistry between Osment's character as a child, and the little girl he favored, than there was later, when Osment and that same neighbor supposedly coupled up.  This sentence went through my mind when I saw them as adults: "Oh, I guess they were together so long, that they take each other for granted now, like brother and sister."  That's how they came across, suggested intimacies notwithstanding.
I am very surprised that the average rating for this movie is as high as it is.  Twelve-year-old's might not have issues with the plot, but when it comes to adult viewing, I think there is a lot better fare on Amazon than this movie.

This feels like a British film. By that I mean it seems to drag and you are really tempted to fast forward or to skip to the end. I accepted the slow format and realized the director was trying to create characte and mood as the story moved along. That is the main flaw with the film. However, once the groundwork and character development was laid down, the film began to pick up and by the end of the film I was caught off guard and blown away with the solution. I would recommend, but warn you it will take dedication to get to the interesting part. Unfortunately, you need the slow part ot understand the rest of the film, so don't skip or fast forward.

The unfortunately titled "I'll Follow You Down" (henceforth referred to as IFYD) is a tick-above-average time travel movie with hints of suspense and some wonderful performances by, most notably, Haley Joel Osment, Susanna Fournier and Victor Garber.  Gillian Anderson is also quite good in her portrayal of Marika, Osment's mother who is wrestling with the sudden, 12 year disappearance of her husband (Sewell).

Not knowing his whereabouts takes a tremendous toll on the family, but Garber and Osment develop a time machine capable of projecting them into the past in an attempt to find Osment's father, and basically "correct" the future.

As with all time travel movies you have to suspend inherent disbelief in its scientific possibility and hopefully get sufficiently mesmerized by the story to minimize the scientific impracticality of the feat.

Whereas IFYD doesn't master the art of storytelling it is well written and acted, and carries some emotional punch.  At times it can be overwrought but for the most part director Mehta is good at balancing the technical and the emotional.  Over all a very nicely done little film with emotional punch. 3.5 stars rounded up because it left me feeling quite positive. Had it been titled something like "The Correction" it might have made more impact.

Thoughtfully written this one grabs your attention and holds it until the very unexpected end.  More low-key and realistically emotional than most science fiction films, like the best of them, the story is far more about the people and their very believable relationships than about the technology.  While keeping it's focus on the people involved, it still manages to provide an intelligently written and reasonably plausible scientific scenario while keeping the integrity and motives of the major characters engaging and sympathetic.  No continuity issues at all, no red herrings, and still the ending manages to surprise.  Very well done, fine acting and a moving story.  Highly recommended.
ok

The pace is slow, the production values feel more like TV than film, the plot is improbable, and the world doesn't threaten to end. There are no explosions, evil geniuses, or chase scenes. The story isn't particularly suspenseful. The time travel discussion feels a little silly. I agree with the reviewer who said this movie would have worked better as a stage production; the story is overshadowed by expectations people usually have for a film - it doesn't need to be loud, flashy, or slick, so to the degree that it is, those qualities are extraneous and intrusive. What makes it compelling is that the characters are believable, in part because the acting is understated. The story considers the consequences of time travel on a personal, pedestrian scale. What would happen to a real family if one member left the timeline they shared? In a metaphorical sense, most of us already know; that's why it works. It's got the usual Time Travel Genre philosophical Road Not Taken questions, plus it looks at the losses or gains that come from commitment to a personal vision or passion versus to the people in our lives. It's kind of like a Twinkie filled with caviar.

Captivated by the concept of time travel since a teen, watching Rod Taylor click the decades by in George Pal's original movie, The Time Machine. Read even more on it, too (The Butterfly effect)  Must say most have faded from my memory, except the Pal feature film, Time after Time, and the Time Traveller's Wife.

This one will stick in the memory, though.  It's not really "about" time travel, but the choices men (yeah, men) make chasing ideas, (wars, money, you name it) at the expense of love and family.  Good performance by Haley Joel Osment (the psychic kid in Sixth Sense) as the son who lost his father...and has a chance to reclaim him, ahhh, but the cost!  Nice turn by X-files' Gillian Anderson as the grieving widow and also Victor Garber as the young man's obsessed grandfather.

The scripting is great, the casting is great, the acting is great, the pace is great...and when you add in the fact that,  at one point, I  just *knew* I had it figured out but was dead wrong...you get an excellent movie. It's very believable...despite the fact that it's impossible. I'll be actively recommending it to family and friends. Sit down and give it a watch.. .its very unlikely that you'll be disappointed. I know that I'll definitely be watching it again.

This will be easier for an old movie buff, such as myself to relate to; here is a story about choices.
Here is a man certain of the good outcome of his efforts in pursuit of a goal to make a better world. He seems to strive for stability, a safer world, greater happiness. He thinks he is making a grand gesture.
In time we all learn that there are no true shortcuts. That no one wins in the end. That it is the striving, not the achieving that counts.
Life choices. When someone stands in one of the many decision boxes of life - forks in the road, if you will - it is not so clear that regardless of which path one chooses, at the end of a life, all the good and bad balance out. Any choice will have a cost. Not choosing has a cost.

This is a very well done movie about time travel. It is not a predictable plot nor is it filled with violent or far-fetched scenes. The acting is not the greatest in the world and the reactions of the characters to stressful events is not always believable, but the movie's strong points far outweigh its weaknesses. It contains a viable and scientifically plausible way to create time travel, and it throws numerous plot twists into the mix that keep one's attention. It is a movie well worth viewing.

One of the best - if not the best - movies I've seen about alternate realities and the choices we make in creating this one we're in.  What sets it apart is the emphasis on the humanity behind those choices, providing just enough theoretical foundation for the time-travel premise to satisfy hard-sci-fi fans yet keep the softies engaged. It reminded me of the very best, thoughtful and far-reaching science fiction novellas and short stories of the 60's and 70's (and, sadly, fewer examples in subsequent decades).

Some reviewers have panned this screenplay's "slow" aspects, a reaction that belies the expectation that a "sci-fi" label portends an escapist, mindless plot. They should moan, instead, about how the industry's lowest-common-denominator categorizations shortchange potential audiences from experiencing truly ground-breaking films. Movies that straddle disparate themes like this one (commitment and choice, love and satisfaction, quantum reality and time travel) cannot be pigeon-holed in a term like "sci-fi." Such simple-minded classifications are for the simple-minded.  If this isn't you, then expect way more from this film than you can imagine: human, 3D characters, poignant choices, thought-provoking insights into possibilities beyond our day-to-day familiarity with "reality" as we think we know it.

So if you're looking for another escapist bit of drivel about time-travel and paradoxes and phony science, then do yourself (and anyone you want to tell about this story) a favor and skip it.  If you love sci-fi that stretches your mind and your awareness of reality, then please - please - don't miss "I'll Follow You Down" - you won't be disappointed.

This was an engaging and thoughtful time travel film.  Many of these films are plagued with inconsistencies. This one does a good job of covering most of the potential plot holes.  In addition, the good performances drive you to really like the characters and care about their plight. That's key for driving the more technically minded sci fi fan to forgive the errors, or plot holes that movies like this tend to have.  In the end it is a highly emotional story about what's important to you success, or family. That's a struggle many driven and employed parents can relate to. Especially in this day and age when both parents need to work just to make ends meet. This is a good film. The director remembers that too much techno jargon will bore the audience, so he focuses on the characters and making empathize with them.

This is a thoughtful study of the personal impacts to a family caused by the inadvertent consequences of time travel. Forget the space operas - this film never goes for the cheap thrills but rather focuses on the human aspects and side effects of what would happen if we were to alter our timelines.  Gillian Anderson is understated as the mother of young boy whose scientist-father disappears on a trip to a conference.  To avoid being a spoiler, let me just say that the low rating of this movie on other sites (e.g., IMDB and Rotten tomatoes) is simply inexplicable.  What the heck do people want?  If you are looking for an alternative to big-budget but mind-numbingly stupid summer blockbusters, give this small, intelligent, independent film a chance.

If you've read any of the descriptions, you know that "I'll Follow you Down" deals with the possibility of time travel.  The interesting thing is that this story couldn't have been told without a consideration that time travel could happen, yet the story is more about three generations of a family than it is about whether time travel happened or not.  Good acting throughout and a well-told story drew me in.  While the story is complete in itself, I could have watched more about the family and what did (or didn't) happen.  4 1/2 stars if I could show it that way

This movie about time travel was a very thoughtful and sensitive.  Unlike most of the science fiction movies today, it does not rely on special effects.  It is about human thoughts and feelings.  It reminds me of the old Jimmy Stewart movie, "It's a Wonderful Life."  It asks the question, what would life be like if I were not around?  It makes the viewer think about time travel and its possible effects on the world.

Sensitive, time/SF/fantasy film. More in the realm of speculative fantasy fiction, using time travel as a metaphor for the choices we make in life and their consequences and how they play out, you know, the " butterfly effect". Great ending, didn't see it coming and won't spoil. If you dig time paradox, this is for you.

While some reviewers have pointed out that this movie lacks the sci-fi weapons and action that we've come to expect from the genre these days, that is not a flaw.  The story is about love, intellectual passion, and inevitability.  There were some cliche type moments, such as Grace announcing that she's pregnant, which was an obvious plot maneuver to make the character Erol focus on the decision that he alone had to make--travel back and save his father and set the time line right, or accept that these things happened and live the life that he has since started.  At this point, I have to comment on the one real flaw that I saw with this story.  Grace has a miscarriage, which really makes Erol's decision easier.  The movie could have dealt so much more with regret over past actions and inactions, but by taking his "becoming a father" away, it veered in another direction.  He says something to the effect that he's always had the feeling that something was telling him that this wasn't the life he was supposed to live.  In essence, it got a bit metaphysical, when it should have stayed philosophical.

To be clear, though, he doesn't mean that he wasn't supposed to live parts of his life.  He believes that he was supposed to fall in love with Grace, and he tries to write out a time line on a brick wall with the important events after his father's disappearance.  I was expecting him to try to insert some trick into his return that would ensure that certain things would happen again.

I thought it was a strong point that Erol kills himself in front of his father to force his hand, but I also wonder if this is another mechanism to make a decision for someone in the film.  In the end, I'm a sucker for a happy ending, and this movie had it.  They didn't overdo the moment when little Grace comes up behind the father when he returns, hinting that things would click between Erol and Grace in this corrected time line.

Also, on more than a few occasions I was taken out of the movie by his forced delivery and the noticeably drug out scenes.  Combine all of this with the lack of chemistry between his counterpart and the oddly chosen background score - which had a tendency to over power the dialogue and seemingly not fit the mood of the scene - I was distracted and stopped paying attention more often than I cared for.  Again, the premise was not bad but the movie seemed to fall a little flat.

This is an interesting little sci-fi film.  I had never heard of it before, but it has Haley Joel Osmont and Gillian Anderson among other actors that are less well known.

It is essentially story focused, so there isn't a lot of special effects.  I enjoyed it because it is one of those movies which is thought provoking and doesn't necessarily treat the viewers as children that need every detail spoon fed to them.

The only reason I didn't give it more than three stars is because I felt like the story could have gone further than it did.  There is plenty of resolution for the main characters, but it seemed some of the larger philosophical issues were not addressed.  Nonetheless, this movie is worth viewing once if you're a fan of thought provoking sci-fi films.

As a Sci-Fi fan with a particular interest in time travel movies, I thoroughly enjoyed this adaptation of the HG Wells classic. Suspense builds as the viewer faces the possibility of changing the past, is it morally acceptable to do so, what would I say to my younger self and what would the consequences be in the present? These complex issues are logically presented while still managing to be entertaining.

You will want to pay close attention, because little oddities later become key events that will startle you and leave you feeling like you have gone back in time and changed your present! When you add in the romance, mystery, and a surprising ending, you have a very enjoyable and thought provoking movie experience.

I read where this was a tale with twists and turns and keeps you guessing. I found the opposite to be true. The movie is fairly well put together, but any SciFi fan worth their salt has read or seen many tales about time travel and its inherent risks. I found all but the very last few minutes of the movie very predictable. A man solves a math equation that allows him to create a stable wormhole to the past. Bad things happen in the past that change the current timeline. His son figures this out, and follows him back to attempt to fix things. I can name at least three similar tales off the top of my head. No points for originally, but better than mothra attacking Tokyo again. Maybe I have seen too many SciFi stories and expect too much, call me jaded if you want, but I like to see content that pleasantly surprises me.

First I'd have to say the film was okay, but not mind bendingly thought provoking. Not wanting to add a spoiler, I'll just say the question of who goes where, when and why is not explained very well. There didn't seem to be any consideration of the well known "butterfly effect" which is usually a component of time travel movies. I wondered if anyone bothered about acquiring period correct money to pay for their coffee in 1946. Why did the father stay in a hotel when he would naturally have stayed with his father? And sorry for you who don't play chess, but at one hour in when the son is setting up a chess position, the board is set up sideways. Yes, there is actually a right way and a wrong way to position a chess board. If this were a typical Hollywood thriller this might be forgivable, but this film aspires to intellectual pretensions, you'd think they'd get that right. I know, I know, only the chessplayers out there will care about this, but don't be too hard on me. I'm sure there's not one chessplayer who doesn't take notice of this in every film that has a chess playing scene. Imagine if it were a football game and the teams were facing off from the sidelines! Would I watch it again if I could go back a few hours in time? Sure. Will I watch it again in the future? Probably not.

Liked it!  Thought that it was really good story line, however, I felt that it lacked some overall elements.  The idea was good, and I really appreciated the actors, especially Rufus Sewell.  Who doesn't like Zen!!  Gillian Anderson is very good as well!  In this story there is a well educated strong independent woman whose husband disappears.  She becomes obsessed with his disappearance and somehow believes that he has left them and run off with another woman.  This obsession drives her mad, very depressed, and finally, she can't take anymore and ends her own life.  While I might be out of touch, does this still happen?  She had looks, money, job, respect in the community, family support.  All I know is that I have never met a woman like this and question their existence??  Lastly, who doesn't like Albert Einstein?  The need for confrontation questioning of Einstein is unclear, and adds to a confusing story line at best.

Wow, was this bad!

The characters are shallow, unbelievable, cliche, and boring -- all at the same time! One of many examples: The wife finds her vanished husband's wallet and cell phone tucked in a desk drawer at Princeton, and the writers don't even give her a single onscreen moment to say, "Hey, did he walk out on us?" They don't even let anyone else ask that question. Somehow we're all supposed to get that he...what?...they never consider any possible explanations at all.

The Albert Einstein references made me groan, as did the whole gifted mathematician shtick.

And, off topic, but grownup child actors look weird most of the time. As children, they're chosen for their archetypical "child-like" features. Like the "I see dead people" kid looks so whiny and sensitive and in psychic pain. As a grownup, guess what? He still looks all whiny. Only now he's about a foot too short for the rest of the actors and his scruffy beard makes no sense on his whiny, babyfat face. Oh and also he can't act.

Really, "Made in Canada" is all you need to know to realize you should avoid this film.

I'm sorry but Haley Joel Osment is not a good actor, and I couldn't get past fixating on his face with kid-sized eyes in an adult face. Ugh, Amazon reviews failed me big-time here. Sorry to see Gillian's career has fallen so low, but at least she will be back in the short X-Files reboot series.

Time travel can be tricky in this case it wasn't thought through his dad didn't come back from a trip his family didn't know what happen to him. His young son was a genius so was his father in law, between the two they theorized what happen to him after twelve years later. The father in law wanted to repudiate what he did his son wanted nothing to do with it but his mom passed and his wife lost their baby he wanted to fix that but his wife found out about what he had in mind and pleaded for him not to do it.  To me there is no way to fix the past if you did would everybody's life on earth  change or would the time period continue you left behind the only difference the wife would be left alone to live out her life. If he did find his father in the past and talked him into going back to the exact minute he left he couldn't come back because there would be two of him one young and him older. It's enough to drive you crazy.

This movie is more like a drama than sci-fi. However, it was an enjoyable film. The story follows the characters through the struggles of finding a solution to a problem that in this case is a time travel problem. Other than one violent event it would make a great family film. Haley Joel Osment demonstrates that he can do great work in an adult role. Being a fan of Gillian Anderson from her X-Files days it was nice to see her in a different role, although it was still a sci-fi role.

The story in "I'll Follow You Down" deals with a lot of science material tied together through emotional character study but you don't have to be a smarty to follow along. Maybe to argue the laws of physics and such one would need to bone up on wormhole theories, quantum physics & mechanics but most people will be drawn in by the character drama that unfolds in the film. The cast is top notch and give moving performances with no overdrawn grandiosity, just straight forward compassionate well developed characters that really make the story enjoyable. The sci-fi or scientific theory aspect of "I'll Follow You Down" is written more matter of fact and what I imagine would be elementary so a good foundation of "Star Trek" or other sci-fi knowledge really works well in that element of the material. I did phase out a bit over "time line corrections without complicating things" because that goes over my head, but I still found everything relatable without being too wordy.

There is very little special effects in the film, most things boil down to a standard musical score that pulls at emotional elements of the film, there is a small practical effect and lighting effect against props to sell the "time machine" aspect that works just fine and without overstating the moment. "I'll Follow You Down" is really a family drama that has some sci-fi attached to it but mostly it is a well directed, well acted and completely executed drama that is enjoyable to watch. I enjoyed the film, the cast was great. The story is sweat and Haley Joel Osment gives a a commendable performance.

While I liked the performance of Gillian Anderson in this movie, and I wanted to love the movie, I found it to be only O.K.

The storyline was interesting and was along the lines of what I would normally like, but it fell flat in some way.  I will say that the movie kept me somewhat surprised, but there was just something about it that did not capture me or my imagination.

SPOILERS!

The premise in my opinion was that because a scientist, father and husband had gone back in time and not returned, he pushed his family onto an alternate timeline that should never have occurred causing negative consequences for the rest of their lives.  It caused a hole in their lives where he was meant to be.

The problem is that the movie did not sell me on that premise.  Yes, bad things happened.  Bad things happen in peoples' lives all the time.  Who is to say bad things would not happen if the scientist had never gone back in time.  The movie just did not sell me on that concept.  Yes, I wanted it to be fixed.  I wanted the family to be happy.  It was just something about how it played out with the son that made the movie only O.K. to me.

This was an intriguing story dealing with issues we usually don't think about regarding time travel. Gillian Andersen was brilliant as usual and I always enjoy seeing Rufus Sewell. Victor Garber fit in well as Gillian's father. What spoiled the entire movie for me was casting Haley Joel Osment as the adult son of Andersen and Sewell. Could they have found a more genetically unlikely actor? I kept thinking a reference would be made to him being adopted but it never came up. I have nothing against Osment as an actor but unfortunately, it was hard for me to suspend disbelief for the story with this obvious casting gaffe. So I'm awarding three stars for the plot minus a half star for the casting for a total of 2 1/2 stars.

I liked this movie. It kept my attention until the end. It makes you wish you could go back in time and change any one key element that brought you to the timeline you live in. How much would be changed with one different decision? Even if it were possible, that is the question no one can answer for sure. So, would you risk it to possibly make the world you live in different? What if you had to die in one timeline to live the life you really want in another? Endless questions come to mind, but still a good movie.

As I watched this flick I was struck by the fact that it's a very good representation of what family life should be, ie: people who actually love, respect and care about one another. Each actor was cast in traditional roles (husband, wife, son, grandfather) that seems to be a thing of the past on the big screen. Also the plot was well served by the limited special effects utilized. Although the surface story centered on time travel the real content was in the relationships that were emotionally played without going over the top. And as always, it's a pleasure to see the the lovely Ms Anderson in anything she cares to grace. This woman projects (imo) her own style of beauty that is at once quite appealing while being unique to her. It was also nice to see Haley Osment finally get over that horribly awkward phase he went through. While not a dynamic actor by any means he was well suited to this part and held his own throughout.

I'll follow you down is a diamond in the rough.  The always lovely Gillian Anderson must have leapt into this role, and the opportunity of being associated with an extraordinary love story.  It's almost a spoiler to admit up front, here is a tale of time travel gone terribly awry.

There exists this machismo, perhaps is the best adjective.  When we imagine the potential of time travel, were ever tempted to presume our contemporary collection of data would give us an edge over any less mature version of ourselves we might run into at an earlier stage of the game.  Against this presumption the script writers have launched a frontal assault.  Although it's tempting to loiter on the relativistic stage of quantum possibilities, I found the solutions presented to be drastic and shocking.

For my part, even if I could somehow transmit my data backwards to a school days incarnation of myself, I'd probably do it all again.  Even with the thought that love might come once again, only for a season, I'd exchange every ounce of magic again for that brief chance.

I just saw this on Prime Instant Video and I didn't have any expectations going in, I didn't even look to see the actors.  I was surprised to see Gillian Anderson who I've liked since the X-Files, and Osment who I haven't seen as an adult actor and I think not since the Sixth Sense.  All the acting in this movie was really well done.  I'm a huge sci-fi fan and I usually look for something like Prometheus, Interstellar, Pitch Black, Pandorum, etc., but this movie kept me interested in finding out the ending.  For such a low key movie I'm surprised I'm giving it this high of a review.  There were no big special effects, no over-the-top fight scenes, no laugh-out-loud moments, and not even that unique of a plot.  The actors and the story keep you wanting to see what happens in the end.  I was impressed with Osment's acting as a lot of kid actors turn out to be disappointing as adult actors, but he's good.

*****SPOILER**************************************************** The one thing I found really odd was when Erol explains everything to Grace, instead of her being amazed and asking how this is even possible, or just thinking her boyfriend is a nut and lost his mind, she just assumes he's going to do it and change their lives and they get into a huge fight over it.  I can envision if other people did this movie they might have had Grace go off and mention something to her boss, then her boss tries to steal their work and that gets into a whole sub-story, or they might have Grace try to stop Erol and sabotage his work, but this movie just stays on track all the way through, which was refreshing.********************END SPOILER*************************************

This movie was pretty bad...  Sections were ok, but when they were strung together, there is just a disconnect overall.  Many scenes were so unbelievable I can't imagine they would happen in real life.  Analogy?  Somebody punches you in the face, so you become an astronaut to fly to moon.  You want a candy bar, but your girlfriend chops off your fingers because your room is painted white.  That's how this movie feels...  It's so badly disconnected that it actually gets frustrating to watch.  It's a B film with some good acting, like a good pastry chef with amazing ingredients that just cut the cake wrong in the end.  Sure there's a cool story line, and the actors do great in their scenes, but that's not enough to save the movie.  Overall, just hard to watch and follow...

Well done and worth watching as a whole . I did feel that Haley Joel Osment was not quite the actor this movie needed. He's missing something in the range of his acting that let's you believe he's a tortured genius. His demeanor and emotive ability did not range very far, plus the very wooden Susanna Fournier wasn't written to do much either so there wasn't much more than trope style acting lesson problems for Susanna Fournier to act out.  Aside from that I really appreciated Victor Garber and Gillian Anderson for their acting pieces.  At least they each had their own struggle and almost their own stories to carry in which Osment existed but never truly felt like he was in the same of acting .  Rufus Sewell also looked like he could have used a better scripted part and his talents were somewhat under-utilized with what was left for him. The plot skeleton was excellent and the summation while somewhat expected was specifically well done. I just wish there was more meat on the bones and that perhaps a stronger actor than Osment was tapped to carry it off.

I'LL FOLLOW YOU DOWN is a well-made science fiction film about time travel, dire loss, and the desperate desire to go back and "fix" things. When a brilliant physicist named Gabriel (Rufus Sewell- DARK CITY, THE SHE CREATURE) vanishes without a trace, it devastates his wife, Marika (Gillian Anderson- TV's THE X-FILES) and son, Erol (Haley Joel Osment- THE SIXTH SENSE). Years later, Marika is still haunted by the disappearance, nearly unable to function. Erol, while going through agony of his own, discovers that his grandfather has been working on something that just might hold the key to the entire mystery. Osment is quite good as the main character of the story, and makes me wonder where he's been all these years. Ms. Anderson plays a minor, though important role, that she pulls off w/ ease. Sewell is only in the movie for a few minutes. There's drama, tension, and an emotional quagmire to balance out the scientific elements. In the end, this is a tale of love, hope, and human ingenuity. Very much worth seeing...

The ideas used to describe how such events in the past could change the life lines of people in the future were made quite believable and, of course, modern science and mathematics is replete with deductive reasoning about parallel time lines and altered time lines through the use of theoretical calculations.  How one would carry out such travels is always the perview of the story teller, and this movie is not different.  However, it was made to be entertainment and, I believe that they succeeded in that goal.

The problem with this movie is that it has a great premise and a somewhat unique angle on a familiar theme, but struggles to deliver as powerfully as it could.  One issue being that there are too many of the typical unrealistic conversations, reactions, responses that are clearly only there to make it easy to take the story where it needs to go - a common problem with any story telling to be sure - perhaps due to time constraints or just plain unimaginative dialog writing.  It's like plenty of other stories out there - disappointing when you think of what it could have been if only seemingly small modifications were made.  It's easy to criticize, especially when you aren't in the shoes of the director, writer, etc. - especially when you don't have experience in what you're criticizing.  So sure, maybe I couldn't have done better, but I'm relatively certain it could've been done better.  And as long as I'm in the easy seat of judge, before I'm through I'll also say I'm not sure if I expected, but I wanted to see better acting from HJO.  Still, my take is that a watered down version of a compelling story is often still worth checking out.  All the more so if your imagination can help blur the bad parts, enhance the good, and fill in what's missing.

Pacing is not bad, special effects are limited, leaving a bit too much to the imagination when it comes to the so-called wormhole. The use of relativistic cosmology is getting tired. When will we see sci-fi based on more contemporary mappings of reality? I'm talking about real quantum and electric universe cosmology. Relativistic cosmology with all of its wormholes, black holes, dark matter, etc., etc., is nothing but mathematical fidgeting to keep economic systems in place based on old science which is NO LONGER VALID. Science fiction based on these old and tired models will never receive more than 3 stars from me, so I guess this means that desdite this major fault, it's not a bad movie.

Other than that, it was a complete waste of time, and particularly un-intelligent for something as sophisticated as time-travel. To give you an example:

In the film, more emphasis was put on the "formula" for time-travel (aka: math equations on a chalk-board) than any actual thought-provoking time-travel planning. Plots a little like this:

- Here's a genius. .... He doesn't look like one, ...he doesn't act like one, ... just trust us.
- Here's that same genius struggling to solve a time-travel equation.
- Here's that same genius being an idiot after finally solving it.
- The end.

I haven't been posting reviews for a bit  sorry about that. It has been one of those months, but hopefully things will smooth out soon. (Isnt that what we all hope?

Not being able to sleep, I pulled out my knitting and a cup of decaf and sat down to watch a movie. Cruising around Amazon Prime Video, I found Ill Follow You Down. Gillian Anderson and Haley Joel Osment. The blurb says: After the disappearance of a young scientist on a business trip, his son and wife struggle to cope, only to make a bizarre discovery years later  one that may bring him home. OK, that sounds interesting  or mind numbing, it is always so hard to tell. The movies I have flipped through lately have been real stinkers, but I like Gillian Anderson, so I settled back to watch.

Victor Garber Actor Victor Garber attends Vanity Fair Party for the ...Directed by Richie Mehta, the movie is listed as drama-mystery. The mystery is there  what happened to Marikas husband, and Erols father after he touched down in New Jersey and his father-in-law, played by the erudite Victor Garber, drops him at Princeton University in Albert Einsteins old laboratory space? What were the crates that he had delivered to the lab? (And what, by the way, was the fathers name? I didn't really catch it!)

This isn't really what I would call a drama per se. It is more of a morality tale in the end, set in a scientific/science fiction setting. Filmed on a minimal budget in Canada the story is slow to develop. As another reviewer says, the pacing and filming is more on the level of a morality play in three parts than the type of shock and awe portrayal that todays science fiction flicks seem to wallow in. Not to say I don't love some high action/adventure scifi that is so common today, but the slow pace and psychological and sociological questions brought to light kept me awake instead of putting me to sleep as I went into it thinking it would. There are questions of how life can change in an instant, and how our personal choices can make, or destroy, the lives of everyone around us in a widening gyre, from a single, selfish action. I have to say, the poster/cover for the movie, done all in blue, fits the concept.

As I said, this isn't SciFi Rock n Roll  but if you want a quiet, thoughtful movie with an interesting concept, you might try this out. It isn't the best developed film I have ever seen, but it is pleasant, and leaves the viewer with food for thought.

Three well-performed love stories (in three generations). Four deaths and three broken hearts. Two alternate realities with the characters in each seeking survival and happiness in the only life they know--or not. Only one possible conclusion with almost Shakespearean consequences for making the wrong choice. A gentle, human-centered plot avoids the boringly repetitive thrills and chills that ruin so many Hollywood efforts. Not afraid to present characters who value thoughtfulness, education, logical reasoning, remembering family, keeping promises, and making compassionate choices in the interest of the greater good. These values are not trivially presented; they are integral to the plot. Recommended for all ages.

I honestly disagree with most of the reviewers here, even those who this movie equivalently. This isn't about staying ahead of the viewer anymore that it is about time travel per se. This is a story about losing someone you love (or need) and the consequences of refusing to move on. If you liked "The Leftovers", "Memento", or the short lived TV series "Awake" you will probably recognize the subtext here as well. All the rest is just fodder for the sci-fy nerd demographic.

On that note, it also has Scully acting across from the kid who sees dead people. Just saying.

While watching this movie, I felt the same sense I used to have when watching the original Twilight Zone episodes back in the day. A very good short story (one with unanticipated twists and turns), turned into a simple screen play (one that could be filmed on a handful of simple sets, with not a hint of computer generated imagery), cast with well-known actors playing character roles. Add to that the emotional drama of tortured souls who want the world to be better, and the extra twists and turns allowed by a feature length film, and you have a genuinely captivating movie.

Don't get me wrong -- I've enjoyed Transformers, Avengers, etc. But after a decade of computer generated battle scenes, I'd forgotten how much I enjoyed old-fashioned science fiction story telling and stage-style acting. It was a genuine treat.

The movie is slower paced than action adventure flicks, especially up front, and there's not a radical new time travel twist here. What you will find is a good story, that follows an arc you probably didn't expect. And you'll feel the angst of the characters, and understand and believe how their loves and turmoils drive the actions that propel the story to its surprising end.

I wish the industry were producing more movies like this.
