While the movie was somewhat slow in pace and the story not as fleshed out as it could have been, overall I thought the acting of the two principal actors was good and believable. The movie kept my interest not through the science fiction alone which initially inspired me to watch, but through the drama of the characters struggling with the moral dilemma brought about as a result of the science fiction aspect of the story. The last 5 minutes of the movie had the most emotional impact on me but I think that it was worth the wait. I was left tearing up because of it. I thought it had a good ending. It's not the best movie I've seen, but it's certainly not bad. Worth a watch in my opinion.

If you are into time travel stories, as I am, this is a worthwhile movie to watch. The film is serious and engaging, with very good performances from Gillian Anderson and Haley Joel Osment. The plot focuses on a gifted young man who feels as though his life has been gradually falling apart since the disappearance of his father a decade earlier. The young man eventually learns that his father was working on a time travel experiment, and so he attempts to recreate his father's work in order to discover what became of him.

My main criticism of the film, and the reason I cannot give it more than three stars, is that while it does an excellent job discussing the potential downsides which could result from tampering with the past, the film does not do a sufficient job of revealing the actual outcome of the young man's journey to rescue his father. Instead, the story leaves it up to the viewer to decide how the story might eventually unfold.

Overall, it is a good story with good acting, but the ending may leave you with an empty feeling and wishing for more of the story to be told.

There was a lot of potential for the writer/director to add a couple more twists to the movie to make it more interesting both from a time travel perspective and from a story-telling perspective.
There were two times I remember when a mystery was being revealed; when Sal (the grandfather) revealed that he was working on Erol's father's research, he just sprung it on him all at once.  This should have been played out over several scenes to build the suspense and mystery.  Some time could have been removed from the beginning portion of the movie where they were establishing the family's perfect life and deep love for one another but it was a bit slow and could have been done more efficiently.
Another time was when Erol revealed who he was to his father.  Again, should have taken more time for this revelation to develop to make it more interesting.

Good sci-fi yarn, good stay-at-home date flick, solid entertaining B-movie, suitable for the entire family (a rarity these days). Though well acted, the plot was full of holes, avoid thinking too much and just enjoy the story.  I'll skip the usual time travel issues (Grandfather Paradox, etc.) and dwell on the one little thing that bothered me the most.

If you traveled back in time from 2012 to 1946 to intercept your father and convince him to return to the correct time line of year 2000, what in the blue blazes would compel you to take a circa-2012 MacBook computer with you??!!  Wouldn't it have been more prudent to take back paper-based pictures of the basement wall?  You're at Princeton for crying out loud, the place was crawling with the top scientific and mathematical minds of that time. Imagine what could have happened if just one of them came across a 2012 MacBook!

You commit suicide in 1946 because you can't return to the alternate 2012 where everything is wrong. You obviously can't return to 2000 and risk encountering your younger self. And if you remained alive in 1946, your presence could alter the timeline again in ways you could not possible imagine or plan around.  By deliberately taking yourself out of the equation, and forcing dad to return to 2000, the timeline can be reset to its original configuration.  I have issues with that scenario but as a movie plot point it seems to work.

But there's that darn 2012 MacBook hanging around.  The grownup "kid" is dead in 1946 so he can't take the computer back to alt-2012 and dad can't very well leave the thing behind; he would have had to hang around in 1946 long enough to find a way to completely destroy the machine, much like what happened in Terminator II where the T-888 commits suicide by lowering himself into a cauldron of melted steel.  But the longer dad remains in 1946, the greater the probability that something will happen to him or the computer is not destroyed.  See the dilemma?

So dad really can't risk staying in 1946 for too long and potentially screwing up THAT timeline; he has no other choice but to take the computer with him back to year 2000.  Now then -- although dad is back home, the MacBook is NOT. He'll have to hide it somewhere until it can be completely destroyed;  you can't leave ANY piece of it behind for someone to accidentally discover, we learned this from the Terminator franchise.

Just to see HOW screwed up things could get, may I suggest a brilliant low-budget indie-film called "The Primer".  If you found this film a bit lacking, that one will surely blow your socks off -- you'll need to watch it at least twice.
Fantastic!

This is mostly a people drama versus a science fiction.

For those that care, this is a "clean" movie other than a few f-bombs. So if that matters to you or kids who may be watching, be aware.

Where the science fiction comes into play is how and why Rufus Sewell is missing from most of the movie. Also, his now grown son, Haley Joel Osmet and father-in-law Victor Garber, try to reverse engineer the how and why of how he's missing.

Gillian Anderson has a small bit part in the movie. So fans of her won't get much out of her bit part.

I'm okay with that, as the drama of the characters is what carries the movies. That combined with the science fiction aspects/theory discussions -- at least for me -- made for a very interesting movie. I'd watch the stage play version of this!

The movie asks one core question: What kind of ripple effects do decisions in our past, have on our lives today? Could we change those effects or at least re-shape them if we could travel back in time and get a do-over?

OVERALL: If we put ourselves in the place of the characters the reactions are logical and the overall story thought provoking. Everything well acted. No CGI for this sci-fi, as it's not needed.

I am an electrical/systems engineer (40 years) any my father has a Ph. d in Theoretical Physics which is also a favorite study of mine. I have also been a Sci-Fi fan since 1964 starting at the age of 8. This is one of the best paradox/split reality stories I have read or seen in this entire time other than the Dean's (RAH): "All You Zombies", a short story that has also been made into the excellent movie: "Predestination".

Time travel has been a favorite of sf authors for over a hundred years but, most (if not most of all) deal with the spectacular, or the fantastical. These two stories deal with the 'every day person's'  point of view; this one dealing with the question and the most plausible result of what has been described as the butterfly effect. The person traveling has no effect on the timeline visited, but completely disrupts what should have been the individual's future or the future of those around the traveler's life from the initial start of travel event. In this scenario the causality surrounding the flow of time creates an unstable reality that will endeavor to correct itself crating a ripple effect that expands from the initial start of the event that could expand to the total unraveling of reality if the flow is not corrected. In this case, it is the continuous existence of the protagonist's father in the timeline he started from. The solution to this issue in the film was excellently done, if (maybe) a little extreme. The Robert Heinlein story mentioned here covers the highly philosophized/discussed topic of the 'chicken or the egg' concept which is as far as I will go describing this movie here.

An excellent film and story that should leave you thinking for a long time.

A real good plot- right on target with the year 2015 and timeline.net I would share this movie with any and everyone whom seeks to share and expose the truths we have had in our hands but kept hidden-for the most wrong reasons. Four and a half SPLENDID Stars. "I'll Follow You Down" is a time travel mystery revolving around a family of geniuses and a missing person. The Whyte family is shown as a very close, loving, somewhat troubled family in the beginning, but soon physicist Gabe (Rufus Sewell) disappears while on a business trip. As the leads dry up and the years pass, taking its toll on the mother (Gillian Anderson) and the grownup son (Haley Joel Osment), the grandfather (Victor Gaber) reveals he's been developing Gabe's notes and theorizes they are about time travel. This is a fascinating film that shows it is not always necessary to have a big budget, mind blowing CGI, and complicated plots to make a great time travel movie: all they needed here was a great script (courtesy of writer/director Richie Mehta), an outstanding cast that delivers marvelous performances (Susanna Fournier steals every scene she's in), and a shocker of an ending to make it all enjoyable and thought provoking. Highly Recommended. Four and a half TEMPORAL Stars! (Amazon Prime Video, 1:32 minutes, Not rated.)
The ending shocked me and moved me, and then I felt it had been worth sitting through all the boring moments and dialogue in order to get to it.  Trust me on this, be patient and wait for the ending!

I was really surprised how enthralling a concept this movie had.  The acting was excellent; (big names), and we get to see "Sixth Sense" actor Haley Joel Osment all grown up, and still a fine actor but with a few extra pounds, ( I found this distracting), but got over it as the movie progressed with its fascinating plot of time travel and branching universe theories.  It explores trying to change a powerful event in the past to then encounter random events in the past which negate the effort of stopping the main event.  It brings up the idea that each act has an effect on something else or the humans around it, and we can never fully understand the ripple effect of acts we commit.  The movie also brings up the concept of no matter how well we plan something, quite often "random decisions of others/events can interfere")  Cause and effect in the scheme of the universe are much more complex, this movie shows you that.  Worth a watch.

I just finished posting some criticism for "Alien Rising", a movie I streamed based on the impression I got from this movie, (IFYD).  With a very trim budget, this film tells the best SF with time-travel I've seen since "Edge of Tomorrow".  And it is worth mentioning that "Edge" was a huge juggernaut of a mainline-Hollywood production . . . I actually never checked "Edge's" budget, but with Tom Cruise, all the CGI, big sweeping screenplay stuff, marketing, etc....Think about it: had IFYD only spent $50mil more on marketing,  plus $50 - $100mil on eye candy (be it cgi/casting/screenplay), I bet it would have been a beast of a profit.

There are a lot of adults who, if you just make sure the script follows the known physical laws, and where it flies off into the areas of artistic freedom it at least remains consistent, are going to love the movie.  I should also mention human behavior,  since that is the area of "Alien Rising" that just missed horribly -- I never could figure out why anyone was acting the way they were.  One of the best parts of IFYD is where the guy shoots himself in the head when they are back in 1946 -- it pushes his father to focus on what he needs to do, PLUS it pinches off that loop/paradox of there being too many bodies.

I'll Follow You Down is NOT a typical scifi-suspense-thriller. There are no automatic weapons or time cops. There is no high-tech research centre. There is in fact no "action" as delivered by most cinema these days, and only minimal, situationally necessary violence. The film is presented and paced like a stage play. The first hour (or more) is used to set the stage for the decisive events that occur in the final act, if you will. It is certainly slow-paced and "talkie," and calls the viewer back to another, earlier era in film-making. Honestly, the acting is not gripping, the characters aren't deeply developed, and suspension of disbelief in the technological ideas is difficult, if not impossible. Nonetheless, there is a level at which this modestly-budgeted made-in-Canada effort does succeed. That is, I found myself truly caring how everything would play out for the characters, and for how they would resolve their struggles with their dilemmas... which were mostly further losses following (minor spoiler) a father's disappearance early on. The themes were universal enough to be engaging. I'd say that the majority of the issues addressed were unstated, and the film's resolution of most of them was equivocal at best. The time travel theme has been much better developed elsewhere, yet, this film still had something, perhaps unique, to say. Finally, the "disappeared" father must face a stark dilemma, and the final minutes of the film deliver the moral of the story, which, if simplistic, did not ring false, at least in "this timeline." In terms of contemporary productions, an effort like Continuum develops a far more sophisticated and complex vision of time travel --- one that makes you stretch, and stretch again. This film doesn't do that at all, nor does it attempt to. The idea of time travel is really secondary to the primary and overriding moral theme. But... please allow me to conclude it like this: Had this been a stage production, it would in fact have worked --- and that is not easy to say for most ideas developed in science fiction film. This is a slow boiler for a quiet and contemplative evening, and not much at all like most other science fiction movies.

This is truly a different sort of time travel movie. This film is more about how lives that are left behind are changed whenever someone violates the time stream. "I'll Follow You Down" is a science-fiction exploration of wormholes, parallel universes, love, and the possibility of starting over. An accomplished physicist (Rufus Sewell) mysteriously disappears on a business trip. His wife (Gillian Anderson, "The X Files") and son Erol struggle to get by. Years later, now a young scientist himself, Erol (Haley Joel Osment, "The Sixth Sense") uncovers papers, formulas, a machine, and an amazing possibility. Erol is determined to find his father and restore his family, and he believes time travel is the way to accomplish this.

This is not a mega-budget Hollywood extravaganza. Rather, it is theatrical in style, featuring fairly simple locations and extensive -- though fascinating -- dialogue about the philosophical ramifications of time travel. Erol weighs the pros and cons before contemplating a journey through time, unlike leading characters in most time-travel flicks, who never think ahead and suffer for it. Erol is motivated by grief rather than megalomania. He just wants his family back together again and believes that time travel is the means. Mr. Osment, all grown up, handles an adult, difficult role admirably. Ms. Anderson and Susanna Fournier, as Erol's girlfriend Grace, turn in strong performances.

Bonus extras on the Blu-ray edition include deleted scenes and a making-of featurette.

Scientist Gabe (Rufus Sewell) disappears on a business trip. He leaves his family to wonder what happened for twelve years.  I will not go into the details of the twelve years as that is why you are watching this movie.

However Sal (Victor Garber) the grandfather and scientist in his own right has pretty much discovered what has happened. With Sal's help, Erol (Haley Joel Osment), son of Gabe will attempts to bring his father back and in the process correct for twelve years of mishaps.

We are left with many questions as to what would be the correct course. The tone of the movie is the age old it is not man's place to mess with the universe. Too bad as it had potential.

I was impressed with the cast; Gillian Anderson can act outside of the x Files.  The background music was homemade and depressing. The scenery was believable.
great movie. wish it lasted longer. it felt like it was just starting to begin and then it ended.

Not a big budget SiFi flick, but more of a sweet drama based around a SiFi situation (Time Travel).  It was good to see Haley Joel Osment all grown up, and at first I just kept waiting for him to see dead people everywhere, but his acting eventually made you forget that character from long ago.

I don't care for movies that barely hold my attention just to find out what will happen in the end. This is one of those, at least for me. I will admit the "twist" on the grandfather paradox caught me totally by surprise and is why I gave the movie three stars. No, it is not a bad movie by any means, just not my cup of tea, so to speak.

I remember the reviews I read were positive, the subject matter was of interest to me, but I regretted spending any money to see this. The actors did an ok job but I barely remember any details of the movie that promised twists and turns.
gillian can still make a part. wish she was in a lot more.
This was a good movie.  At first I didn't know how I'd feel with Haley Joel being grown up and acting in an adult role, but he was really amazing.  Really good story line and feel good ending.

This was a shockingly good movie, I don't know why they'd have such great production quality and such an awful, unappealing poster / DVD jacket for the film. It's a hard one to sell because many American movie consumers don't care for more thoughtful, slower-paced films that are absent hundreds of explosions and etc. Great film, I'll look for more from this production team.

Gillian Anderson was truly amazing. What a range she has. I had no idea. And Haley Joel Osment--I confess I had no idea he was still acting but he was excellent. Very believable characters, great ensemble film. Made me think but was still so enjoyable even with the range of deep emotions a film like this elicits. I didn't want it to end as quickly as it seemed to! Watch it, you'll enjoy it!

The story is one of mystery. The father/scientist (Rufus Sewell, not playing the bad guy here) disappears one day without a trace, leaving behind a wife(Gillian Anderson, the goddess of sci fi that looks
really great at this age) and a son (Haley Joel Osment, let me spare you the brain pressure to try to
remember him, he has the kid in AI) . They live a crappy life after that. Enter the grand father (tv star
Victor Garber) who manages to convince the son that his dad has travelled back in time to meet
Einstein. And yes it is all math and crazy physics for a while after that, since both of them decide
to re-create the machine that the father made and try to reach him back into the past.
An easy, kind of boring plot, but again with a really nice end. AND IT HAS A GREAT TWIST!

And if you don't believe me that a sci fi movie can exist without mad aliens and explosions,

Can't say much, not bad, but very slow,... leaned toward 2 stars, but thought the actors were good, so went to 3 starts.

This is a straightforward science fiction time travel/parallel worlds story.  It is so straightforward that I could imagine this having been one of the filler stories in the July, 1957 edition of Amazing Magazine.

Rufus Sewell says good-bye to his wife, Gillian Anderson, and his young son, who will grow up to be Haley Joel Osment.  Then he disappears and Anderson becomes depressed and Osment grows up without a father, but with a really hot girlfriend.  Then, Osment's grandfather figures out that Rufus was playing around with time travel and that if they go back in time and intercept him before he disappeared, the time track will reset itself the way that it should have been.

Of course, no one really knows what that time-line would look like. Would Haley Joel still have a hot girlfriend?  Would Grandpa get a chance at some action with the nice widow who works in accounting? Big, big questions.

The story is mostly presented by dialogue and is fairly obvious and slow going.  The ending is both nice in a maulding sentimental way and surprising. It's kind of fun to see a grown up Haley Joel. Gillian Anderson and Rufus Sewell really only make token appearances in the movie. It's not a bad watch if you like classic time-travel stories.

Rufus Sewell and Gillian Anderson are always amazing, but this movie is more about the loss the wife of the time traveler experiences and her depression that ensues over the long stretch of time that he's gone and not about the sci fi aspects of time travel. If you're looking for a film that captures the moods of those left behind, this could work. If you're looking for true sci fi that transports you, this will leave you fast forwarding until you're at the credit. But long live Rufus and Gillian!

Worth it!

If you like science fiction, watch it.  Acting, script, etc. is what it should be for this story.
I wanted to like this film because I love sci-fi. Frankly, I found it boring, even though I like the actors. It seemed stilted. The writing didn't grab me. Ho hum is my response.

This movie was mostly fun and moving.  Well written and the actors were a perfect fit for their characters.  While there is a serious theme throughout the movie, it was still a light hearted  movie. The twist was really nice. I don't know why I had never heard of this movie but after renting it I felt it was really worth it. It is hard to review without giving anything away but this was a good short sci fi movie.
As a time travel movie buff, I loved this one.  Suspenseful, great storyline, interesting characters...has it all, including a grrreat ending.

right down the line, this one is okay. that's right where it sits on the line. we somewhat care about the characters. we somewhat get some science and there's a kinda science fiction element that borders on cool. but it makes very little effort to follow up on belief or depth. more could have been done to make the 1940's look like the 1940's we imagine it was. not enough time was spent creating a story line we could embrace or care about. too many cooks in the kitchen on this one.
The actors were top notch but the directing and writing left something to be desired. All in all a decent movie to watch just to follow a different storyline and a surprise ending!
Good movie,,,, worth the watching

Very nicely under played by all actors. I always enjoy a good story that involves time travel. The science is thrown at us and doesn't bog us down (we do not try to nit-pick any plot holes because of this) and there are emotional conflicts that are resolved in a satisfying way.

I don't think I would have liked paying full theater prices for this, but for home viewing this was a lovely little movie from Amazon Prime.
This was a very interesting movie.  Very well-acted.  I loved the story and the ending was perfect.

I really enjoyed this film as a thought-provoking study of the path not taken. Acting is excellent, script is good and the story is compelling. I did not see the twist at the end coming but once I did it made perfect sense. Very much in the tradition of The Twilight Zone for sci fi that makes you ponder and wonder. Recommended.

First, I am a fan of time travel so any such premise within my range of belief will find approval. In this story, I found that approval with the exception of the lead actor's fiance character. Cliche'ed to the hilt, she withered under the others. However, don't let that stop you from watching this better than average film. She is easy to ignore.

If you need lots of chase scenes and slo-mo martial arts fight scenes and other such modern day cinematic bangles then this movie is not for you.  On the other hand if you like thinking about the paradoxes of time travel, alternate timelines, realities and parallel universes then you will likely find this movie worth watching.  If this is how you are then I wish there were more people like you.  This movie will not give you the inspiration to transport yourself, temporally, but in my opinion it beats most other movies, and it definitely beats drinking beer and watching football with the rest of the clowns ;)

This definitely will catch you by surprise. I enjoyed the movie a lot. Theres not a lot of "physical action" but it keeps you interested for sure. Very interesting. I will they would have extended the end more and shown more of the outcomes. Good movie.

"Your dad never broke a promise ever and the way he looked at me at the airport, it just looked like he knew something." Marika (Anderson) and Erol (Osment) kiss goodbye to their husband and father at the airport as he leaves for a conference in New Jersey for a few days. When he never returns they begin to worry, when no one can find him they fear the worst. 12 years later Osment is told a secret by his grandfather that may answer the question that has plagued the family for years. I had no idea what to expect from this when I started to watch it. I was interested almost right away but when the time travel thing came up I laughed a little. The more I watched the less absurd it sounded and that actually became the reason I was so sucked in. This is a movie that was actually able to stay one step ahead of the viewer the entire time. Just when you think you know what is going to happen it throws something at you that surprises you right up until the ending that is both shocking and perfect. This is the type of movie that after you watch it all you want to do is tell everyone you know to watch it. That is the beauty of lower budget films. There aren't many blockbuster movies you rave about and think wow my friends need to see this. Overall, this sucks you in and keeps you interested the entire time trying to predict what will come next. I give this a high B+.
An unusual take on a very common sci-fi theme.. Kept me thinking for days after I saw it. The kid became a good and believable actor, and Gillian Anderson delivers a heart-wrenching performance.

This film moves beyond the typical sci-fi time travel scenario. It sensitively explores yet another dimension, a family's traumatic loss and grief. Gillian Anderson's touching performance adds depth and sensitivity to this film. It's worth a watch if only for her performance.

....this is the second time I've watched this. Despite some of the reviews, just watch this for yourself. It's a very good movie. Wish the ending was a little longer... but sometimes maybe what we get is enough. Good acting, good script and well worth the price to rent. Enjoy.

Almost B-Movie-ish. Sadly, WJO is a really bad actor. His lines seem forced, the whole production seems to fall short story and delivery wise, however all of the actors in this are top rate. Gillian Anderson's role is fantastic, she's a knock out as always; but as mentioned it goes in a strange direction. Interesting timetravel movie, but i'd wait for it to hit Netflix/Prime/your medium of choice.
Exactly what I ordered and wanted.

Wow!! Best movie I never heard of. Only rented it because of Rufus Sewell. Hes a great actor and Im working my way through his canon. But this movie has an amazing plot, and Haley Joe Osment tops his Sixth Sense surprise ending. Highly recommend watching it with someone who you can discuss it with.
only ok.
Could have been better.

Wanted to see this movie because I am a Rufus Sewell fan and he along with the remainder actors make up a fine cast for this film. Had low expectation based on ratings.  I am learning to ignore ratings. Held my interest all the way through.  Go for it!
Loved it
I am a science fiction junkie and I really enjoyed this film.  It is drama which not only enhances the plot but gives it real human emotion surrounding the unknown.

As an avid scifi fan, I loved to speculate about time travel, digging out all the logical permutations, e.g. "it won't happen because it didn't."  So I am something of an aficionado of films in this vein.  This is a very good film about it, complete with a detailed ethical dilemma as acted out by wonderful actors in character.  Its great accomplishment is that I was able to completely believe in it while watching and felt moved at the end.  But this isn't for everyone - it is genuine hard scifi, not some fast-paced thriller that will awe by special effects alone.

Recommended.
